snippet.title: Jean Claude Perrottet gives evidence at his sexual assault trial
snippet.content:
Jean Claude Perrottet was having a good Saturday - he applied for a job, caught a bus to the shops, bought a belt and a watch band on sale, and won Monopoly games at McDonald's. "It's been so good today," he wrote in a text message to his older sister, detailing his morning.Photo: AAP "And now I'm going to a ball." But the evening of the University of Sydney's St John's College formal ended very differently.
Mr Perrottet, the younger brother of NSW Treasurer Dominic Perrottet​, is charged with three counts of sexual intercourse with a 19-year-old woman without her consent near the college car park the early hours of October 18, 2015. The 20-year-old has pleaded not guilty.
The jury began to hear Mr Perrottet's version of events for the first time as he sat in the witness box in the NSW District Court on Wednesday afternoon.

Mr Perrottet was working as a cleaner at a medical research centre near the college in the months before he started university, and was invited to the ball by a female friend. He described drinking beers, champagne, gin, and a French martini during the evening, spending time with friends, dancing, and kissing a woman on the dance floor. "I was drunk at that point," Mr Perrottet said. As the night wore on, security guards removed people from the formal's after-party, held in an area of the college known as the Lemon Grove. "I had been kicked out," Mr Perrottet said, adding he was among a large group of people who returned to the party through another entrance. "It was just a bunch of randoms who were in the same predicament." Some time after this, Mr Perrottet is accused of sexually assaulting the young woman among overhanging trees near the Lemon Grove. The court has heard Mr Perrottet then followed the woman back to her dorm room, and her friends told him to leave. The jury watched CCTV footage from the college corridors, which showed a man in a dinner suit coming down the stairs near the woman's room, turning around and returning upstairs. The court at RPA Hospital, soon after the alleged assault. "I remember being on the ground and lying there and saying, 'Stop it, get off me, I don't want to do that'," the woman said. "He kept trying to have sex with me and I was like: 'That really hurts. Stop it.'" She told officers she kissed a man "with a French name", then remembered ending up in the car park with him. "He was having sex with me and I kept telling him to stop," the woman said. Under cross-examination from Mr Perrottet's defence barrister Alissa Moen​, with him. Ms Moen has told the jury Mr Perrottet will give evidence that two of the sex acts were consensual, the other did not happen. The trial continues before Judge Stephen Norrish.
